awd_titl_txt: Carbonylation Methodologies and Strategies for Building Complex Chemical Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemical Synthesis Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Mingji Dai of Purdue University is developing new ways to make complex and medicinally important molecules using carbon monoxide as a one-carbon linchpin and a palladium catalyst to form new bonds. Complex natural products and natural product-like molecules are indispensable in drug discovery. However, their structural complexity necessitates the development of new catalytic synthetic methods for their synthesis. The reactions that Professor Dai and his research group are investigating are helping to address this problem by providing streamlined methods to access these important targets. The products of these studies are also being shared with collaborators to investigate their biological significance. Simultaneously, this work is being used for the education and training of a diverse group of students and scholars.

Professor Dai and his research team are investigating how to generate and intercept acyl-palladium species to design new reactions that rapidly increase structural complexity. This new synthetic methodology is then being applied in synthetic sequences that target challenging natural and non-natural products with potentially desirable characteristics for medicinal studies. In one branch of the research program, transformations involving palladium-catalyzed tandem carbon-carbon bond cleavage and carbonylative lactonization are being studied to synthesize fused bicyclic lactones including complex Stemona alkaloids isolated from plants used in herbal medicine. In a related but distinct part of the project, palladium-catalyzed carbonylative macrolactonization is being explored to synthesize complex macrolides and their derivatives. In the third portion of the program, palladium-catalyzed tandem, carbonylative cyclization is being explored to synthesize natural products that feature electrophilic moieties with the potential for covalent protein modification. Professor Dai is also providing valuable training to postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduate students and preparing these individuals for future careers in the chemical sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Polycyclic and macrocyclic natural products are privileged members of bioactive natural products from which antibiotics, anti-viral drugs, chemotherapeutic agents, immunosuppressants, insecticides, and many other important molecules have been identified. However, their application in various fields especially pharmaceutical industry and agriculture are still far from being fully exploited mainly because of their natural scarcity and structural complexity. Their chemical syntheses persist as great challenges, particularly where the synthetic efficiency and economy are concerned. There is a great need of new synthetic methodologies as well as efficient and flexible synthetic strategies toward these natural products and their analogs in order to unlock their transformative application potential. The scientific goal of this project was to discover and develop new Pd-catalyzed carbonylation strategies and methodologies to build complex chemical structures and streamline the synthesis of bioactive macrolides and polycyclic molecules. The educational goal of this project was to synergistically integrate our research into the education and mentoring of the next-generation synthetic chemists with diverse backgrounds and attract young students to the STEM field. During the course of this NSF support, we have developed a series of novel and enabling palladium-catalyzed carbonylation methodologies and strategies to streamline the chemical synthesis of medicinally important natural products. Cheap, abundant and sustainable carbon monoxide was used as a one-carbon linchpin to efficiently stitch relatively simple starting materials into complex structures with significantly enhanced value. We have used these newly developed carbonylation methodologies and strategies to synthesize a collection of natural products. (i) Using the Pd-catalyzed cyclopropanol ring opening spirolactonization methodology developed in our laboratory, we completed an efficient total synthesis of tricyclic prostaglandin D2 metabolite methyl ester, a clinically used compound for measuring prostaglandin D2 level in patient but has very limited supply. Our synthesis solved the material supply issue and is expected to broaden its clinical use. (ii) We completed the first total synthesis of four bergamotane sesquiterpenes (massarinolin A and purpurolides B, D, and E) featuring an oxaspirolactone core. Our synthesis also helped to revise the chemical structure of massarinolin A, which has demonstrated promising activity against Gram-positive bacteria including Bacillus subtilis and Staphylococcus aureus. (iii) Using a tandem carbonylative Stille Cross Coupling and Diels-Alder reaction to build its trans-decalin system, we completed a concise total synthesis of UCS1025A, which exhibits antiproliferative activity against human cancer cells by inhibiting the telomerase enzyme. Our synthesis provides a versatile approach to prepare other related bioactive pyrrolizidinone-containing polyketides. (iv) Using a Pd-catalyzed cyclopropanol ring opening cross coupling reaction to form the central seven-membered ring and C–H functionalization to install the peripheral functional groups, we completed the total syntheses of hamigerans C, G and I in only 13-14 steps. Hamigeran C and I were made for the first time. This work provided an efficient and divergent approach to access the hemigeran natural products with potent anticancer and antiviral activity. (v) We completed a convergent and efficient total synthesis of the steroidal alkaloid heilonine, isolated from Fritillaria ussuriensis Maxim, a rich source of steroidal alkaloids with broad therapeutic potential. Our synthesis features four selective C–H functionalizations and a Stille carbonylative cross coupling followed by a Nazarov cyclization to build key ring systems, which provides a synthetic platform to access other analogs of heilonine for therapeutic development. Finally and importantly, the project provided valuable opportunity and strong training for undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, helped them to improve their performance, skills, and attitudes, and prepared them for the chemical industry and educational institutes. 

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2024
Modified by: Mingji Dai
